action.action-desc: Ms. Velázquez introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, and in addition to the Committee on Financial Services, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide incentives for employer-provided employee housing assistance, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Housing America’s Workforce Act of 2017.

subsection.text: The Congress finds the following:

paragraph.text: Resurgent housing markets are pricing out low- and moderate-income families and are producing few lower-cost units.

In many markets, housing costs have far outgrown the rate of inflation and the gap between wages and housing costs is widening, pushing affordable housing beyond the reach of an increasing number of working families.

Despite some of the lowest mortgage rates in our Nation’s history, millions of working families still find it extremely difficult to rent or purchase a home. Many workers who fill jobs that provide the backbone of our communities—teachers, firefighters, and police officers—often cannot afford to live in the communities in which they serve.

The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) considers housing affordable when a family spends no more than 30 percent of its monthly income on rent and utilities. Entry-level wage earners with annual incomes of up to $30,000 spending no more than 30 percent of their income on rent can only afford to pay up to $750 for rent. In the high job growth areas, such rents are not readily available.
Affordable housing is the key to creating and sustaining healthy, economically vibrant communities.
The lack of affordable housing across the United States has been shown to cause or contribute to labor shortages.
Under employer-assisted housing (EAH) programs employers provide much needed housing assistance to their employees.
EAH programs are innovative local solutions that have increased affordable housing opportunities for thousands of working families across America while benefiting the economy.

According to findings of the Rutgers University American Affordable Housing Institute, employer-assisted housing increases productivity by reducing commuting time as well as saves money on recruitment and retention.
The future growth of EAH programs will remain dependent upon increasing individual employer knowledge and implementation of these programs.

EAH programs will not solve the Nation’s housing problems but such programs do seek to address the challenge from a new perspective and allow the private sector to play a direct role in promoting housing affordability. Additionally, EAH programs can help to promote redevelopment and reinvestment in distressed communities.

subsection.text: The purposes of this Act are as follows:

paragraph.text: To expand affordable housing opportunities to low- and moderate-income working individuals and families.
To encourage employers, counties, and municipalities to invest in employer-assisted housing programs.

section.header: Tax credit for employer-provided employee housing assistance

subsection.text: Subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (relating to business related credits) is amended by adding at the end the following new section:

paragraph.text: For purposes of section 38, the employer-provided employee housing assistance credit determined under this section for any taxable year is an amount equal to 50 percent of the qualified housing expenses paid by the employer during the taxable year if such expenses are furnished pursuant to a program described in subsection (b).

paragraph.header: Special rule for small business employers

subparagraph.text: In the case of an employer that is a small business employer, paragraph (1) shall be applied by substituting 100 percent for 50 percent.
For purposes of subparagraph (A), the term small business employer means an employer that is a small business concern (within the meaning of section 3 of the Small Business Act) which—

clause.text: is engaged in a trade or business, and
employs one or more individuals in such trade or business.

subparagraph.text: The aggregate amount of qualified housing expenses taken into account with respect to any eligible employee for any taxable year shall not exceed, when added to any qualified housing expenses taken into account for any preceding taxable year with respect to such employee—

clause.text: in the case of homeownership assistance, the lesser of $10,000 or 6 percent of the purchase price of such employee’s principal residence, and
in the case of rental assistance, $5,000.
In the case of any taxable year beginning after 2017, each dollar amount referred to in subparagraph (A) shall be increased by an amount equal to—

subclause.text: the cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 26 U.S.C. 1(f)(3) for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins, by substituting 2016 for 1992.

clause.text: If any amount as adjusted under clause (i) is not a multiple of $50, such amount shall be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, a housing assistance program is a separate written plan of an employer for the exclusive benefit of such employer's employees to provide the qualified housing expenses of such employees and which meets requirements similar to the requirements of paragraphs (2) through (6) of section 127(b).
For purposes of this section—

subparagraph.text: The term eligible employee means any individual—

clause.text: employed by an employer,

whose household income does not exceed 120 percent of the area median gross income (adjusted for household size) for the metropolitan statistical area (as defined in section 143(k)(2)(B)) in which the housing is located, and
in the case of homeownership assistance, who is a qualified homebuyer.

subparagraph.continuation-text: If the housing with respect to such employee is located in a high housing cost area (as defined in section 143(f)(5)(C)), the income limitation under subparagraph (B) shall be adjusted (but not reduced) by the application of the rule under section 143(f)(5) by substituting 120 percent for 115 percent in subparagraph (B)(I) thereof.

subparagraph.text: The term eligible employee shall not include—

clause.text: any individual described in subparagraph (A), (B), or (C) of section 51(i)(1), and
any 5-percent owner (as defined in section 416(i)(1)(B)).

subparagraph.text: The term qualified housing expenses means rental assistance or homeownership assistance towards the lease or purchase of housing.
The term rental assistance means assistance with security deposits and rental payments.
The term homeownership assistance means assistance for the purchase of a principal residence, including—

clause.text: payment of qualified acquisition costs (as defined in section 72(t)(8)(C)),
providing (or reducing the costs of) financing, including the funding of a permanent interest rate buydown,
contributions to second mortgage pools or low interest loan programs accessible to eligible employees,
mortgage guarantee programs for the repayment of any loans in default that are secured by an eligible employee and guaranteed by the employer,
contributions to Individual Development Accounts (within the meaning of section 404(h) of the Social Security Act) which are designated exclusively for the purchase of a home, and
contributions to homebuyer education and homeownership counseling of eligible employees.

paragraph.text: The term principal residence has the same meaning as when used in section 121, except such term shall not include a residence with a purchase price exceeding the greater of—

subparagraph.text: 90 percent of the average area purchase price applicable to the residence, or
3.5 times the family income limit applicable to the eligible employee under paragraph (1)(A)(ii).

The term qualified homebuyer means any individual if such individual (and if married, such individual’s spouse) had no present ownership in a principal residence during the 3-year period ending on the date of the purchase of the principal residence to which this section applies.

If an individual is treated as a qualified homebuyer with respect to any principal residence, such individual may not be treated as a qualified homebuyer with respect to any other principal residence.

paragraph.text: Rules similar to the rules under section 127(c)(5)(A) shall apply for the purposes of this section.

subsection.header: Treatment of employers not able To use entire credit

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, any credit allowable under subsection (a) to any employer described in paragraph (2)(C) may be transferred as provided in this subsection and the determination as to whether the credit is allowable shall be made without regard to the tax-exempt status of the employer.

subparagraph.text: An employer described in subparagraph (C) may transfer any credit to which paragraph (1) applies through an assignment to any other person. Such transfer may be revoked only with the consent of the Secretary.
The Secretary shall prescribe such regulations as necessary to ensure that any credit described in subparagraph (A) is assigned once and not reassigned by such other person.
An employer is described in this subparagraph if the employer is—

clause.text: a State or political subdivision thereof, the District of Columbia, a possession of the United States, or an agency or instrumentality of any of the foregoing,
an Indian tribal government (within the meaning of section 7871) or any agency or instrumentality thereof, or
any entity exempt from taxation under section 501(a).

subparagraph.header: Transfer proceeds treated as arising from essential government function
subparagraph.text: Any proceeds derived by a person described in clause (i) or (ii) of subparagraph (C) from the transfer under subparagraph (A) of any credit to which paragraph (1) applies shall be treated as arising from the exercise of an essential government function.
Any transfer under subparagraph (A) of any credit to which paragraph (1) applies shall not be treated as income for purposes of section 501(c)(12).

subsection.header: Credit allowed as part of general business credit
subsection.text: Section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (defining current year business credit) is amended by striking plus at the end of paragraph (35), by striking the period at the end of paragraph (36) and inserting , plus, and by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.text: the employer-provided employee housing assistance credit determined under section 45S(a).

Subsection (c) of section 196 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by striking and at the end of paragraph (13), by striking the period at the end of paragraph (14) and inserting , and, and by adding at the end the following new paragraph:
the employer-provided employee housing assistance credit determined under section 45S(a).
The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of such Code is amended by adding at the end the following new item:

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2016.

section.header: Exclusion from income of employer-provided employee housing assistance

subsection.text: Part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (relating to items specifically excluded from gross income) is amended by inserting after section 139F the following new section:

paragraph.text: Gross income of an eligible employee does not include amounts paid or incurred by the employer of such employee for qualified housing expenses provided to the employee if the assistance is furnished pursuant to a program described in subsection (b).

subparagraph.text: The aggregate amount of qualified housing expenses which may be excluded under paragraph (1) with respect to any eligible employee for any taxable year shall not exceed, when added to any qualified housing expenses excluded in any preceding taxable year with respect to such employee—

clause.text: in the case of homeownership assistance, the lesser of $10,000 or 6 percent of the purchase price of such employee's principal residence, and
in the case of rental assistance, $5,000.
In the case of any taxable year beginning after 2017, each dollar amount referred to in subparagraph (A) shall be increased by an amount equal to—

subclause.text: the cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 26 U.S.C. 1(f)(3) for the calendar year in which the taxable year begins, by substituting 2016 for 1992.

clause.text: If any amount as adjusted under clause (i) is not a multiple of $50, such amount shall be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50.

subsection.text: For purposes of this section, a housing assistance program is a separate written plan of an employer for the exclusive benefit of such employer's employees to provide the qualified housing expenses of such employees and which meets requirements similar to the requirements of paragraphs (2) through (6) of section 127(b).
For purposes of this section—

paragraph.text: Any term used in section 45S which is also used in this section shall have the same meaning as given such term by section 45S.
Rules similar to the rules under section 127(c)(5)(A) shall apply for purposes of this section.
For purposes of this subtitle, if an exclusion is allowed under subsection (a) with respect to a residence, the basis of such residence shall be reduced by the amount of the exclusion.

subsection.text: Subsection (d)(1) of section 6039D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (relating to returns and records with respect to certain fringe benefit plans) is amended by striking or 137 and inserting 137, or 139G.

paragraph.text: The table of sections for part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by inserting after the item relating to section 139F the following new item:

Subsection (a) of section 1016 of such Code (relating to adjustments to basis) is amended by striking and at the end of paragraph (36), by striking the period at the end of paragraph (37) and inserting , and, and by adding at the end the following new paragraph:
in the case of a residence with respect to which amounts were excluded from income under section 139G, to the extent provided in section 139G(c)(3).

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning December 31, 2016.

section.header: Grants to cover employer-assisted housing program costs

paragraph.text: The Secretary may award a grant to an eligible entity to pay—

subparagraph.text: the operating costs of administering an employer-assisted housing program;
for technical assistance provided by the eligible entity to an employer in connection with such a program; and
for costs associated with promoting, publicizing, or otherwise attempting to distribute information relating to such a program.

paragraph.text: Grants in an annual aggregate total of not more than $5,000,000 may be awarded under this subsection during each of fiscal years 2017, 2018, and 2019.
The Secretary shall award grants under this section on a competitive basis.

subsection.text: To be eligible to receive a grant under this section, an entity shall demonstrate that it is—

paragraph.text: a nonprofit housing organization with a relevant mission and demonstrated track record in housing counseling or employer-assisted housing contracted by an employer to assist the employer in establishing or maintaining an employer-assisted housing program; or

a city, county, town, township, parish, village, hamlet, or other general purpose political subdivision of a State that seeks to establish or maintain, or otherwise participate in an employer-assisted housing program for its own employees.

subsection.text: Each eligible entity seeking a grant under this section shall submit an application to the Secretary at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require.
A grant awarded to an eligible entity under this section shall be used only for the purposes described under subsection (a).

paragraph.text: Each eligible entity receiving a grant under this section shall annually prepare and submit to the Secretary a report that describes the—

subparagraph.text: amount of grant funds expended during the year;
total amount—

clause.text: of funds expended during the year to administer an employer-assisted housing program; and
of down payment assistance provided by such a program;

subparagraph.text: total number of employees utilizing such a program;
number of employees utilizing such a program—

clause.text: who are first-time homebuyers;
who are previous homeowners; and
who live in high-cost housing areas;

subparagraph.text: average—

clause.text: income of employees utilizing such a program;
age of employees utilizing such a program; and
cost of a home purchased under such a program;

subparagraph.text: ethnicity of employees utilizing such a program; and
number of housing units affected by such a program.
Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall establish a national clearinghouse, including a website, designed—

clause.text: to provide information about employer-assisted housing programs to—

subclause.text: Federal, State, and local government entities; and
interested groups, businesses, persons, and organizations; and

clause.text: to collect and disseminate the information gathered from the reports required under paragraph (1).

subparagraph.text: The Secretary shall ensure that—

clause.text: each report submitted under paragraph (1) is posted to the website of the national clearinghouse established under subparagraph (A); and
the website of the Department of Housing and Urban Development provides a hyperlink to such reports on the website of the national clearinghouse.

subsection.text: As used in this section:

paragraph.text: The term Secretary means the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
The term nonprofit housing organization means any organization that—

subparagraph.text: the Internal Revenue Service has ruled is exempt from income taxation under paragraph (3), (4), or (5) of section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986; and
has as its stated purpose to produce, maintain, operate, or promote affordable housing.

subsection.text: There are authorized to be appropriated $5,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2017, 2018, and 2019 to carry out this section.

A study of employer-assisted programs shall be carried out in accordance with subsection (b) for the purposes of evaluating the effects of the tax benefits provided under sections 3 and 4 and the grant program established under section 5 on—

paragraph.text: such programs; and
the private sector resources leveraged to further fund such programs.
The Comptroller General of the United States (in this section referred to as the Comptroller General) shall conduct the study required under subsection (a).
The study required under subsection (a) shall include an analysis and summary of—

subparagraph.text: the total number of—

clause.text: employers participating in employer-assisted housing programs;
States that have enacted employer-assisted housing program legislation; and
States considering enacting such legislation;

subparagraph.text: the extent to which Federal funds are being used to support employer-assisted housing programs;
the size and nature of existing Federal, State, and private employer-assisted housing programs;
the types of assistance offered to employees under employer-assisted housing programs;
the distribution of employers offering employer-assisted housing programs, including a review of the—

clause.text: geographic distribution of such employers;
industry distribution of such employers; and
size distribution of such employers;

subparagraph.text: the extent to which employer-assisted housing programs are located in high-cost housing markets;
the extent to which employers are able to, and have made, use of the tax benefits provided under this Act;
the information contained in the reports submitted under section 5(e); and

any other information that the Comptroller General determines would be relevant and helpful to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (in this section referred to as the Secretary) in evaluating the effects of the tax benefits provided under sections 3 and 4 and the grant program established under section 5.

subsection.text: In conducting the study required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall consult with—

paragraph.text: appropriate Federal, State, and local government entities; and
interested groups, businesses, persons, universities, and organizations.
Not later than January 1, 2020, the Comptroller General shall submit to the Secretary an interim report on the findings of the study required under subsection (a).
Not later than December 31, 2021, the Comptroller General shall submit to the Secretary a final report that describes—

subparagraph.text: the findings of the study required under subsection (a); and
any conclusions and recommendations of such study.

subsection.text: There are authorized to be appropriated $1,000,000 to carry out this section.
